hypothesis: Water and temperature additively influence annual growth,
...typically over different time windows.
Climate and DBH have additive effects on growth,
…and interactive effects are also common
There is an additive effect of year.
Drought limits tree growth, but the response to water is nonlinear
The time window over which water influences growth is often $\ge$ 9 months.
Growth respones to precipitation are predominantly positive,
...but positive responses decelerate or decline at high precipitation.
supported: 32 / 34 species-site combinations with positive first-order terms

hypothesis: Temperature has predominantly negative, nonlinear effects on growth.
The time window over which $T$ influences growth rarely exceeds 3 months.
Annual growth responds more strongly to $T_{max}$ or $PET$ than to  $T_{min}$.
Growth respones to $T$ are predominantly negative, particularly at higher $T$.
However, there are cases where growth increases under warmer $T$.
Climate sensitivity varies with DBH.
Water and DBH have an interactive effect on growth.
Temperature and DBH have an interactive effect on growth.
Growth rate, by any metric, varies nonlinearly with DBH.
Ring width increment ($RW$) declines with $DBH$ for trees established in the open,
...but increases with $DBH$ for trees established in the understory.
Basal area increment ($BAI$) increases to a peak at intermediate DBH and then declines.
Biomass increment ($\Delta AGB$) increases to a peak at intermediate DBH and then declines.
Growth rates of most forest tree populations have declined through time due to demographic and successional changes.
In secondary or disturbed forests, growth rates of most species have declined.
In old-growth forests, growth  rates of some species has declined,
….whereas others have increased.
